questions.question: A woman with a family history of breast and ovarian cancers underwent genetic testing. Sheis found to have a BRCA1 gene mutation. Which of the following is she at risk of developing?
questions.explanation: Individuals with BRCA1 mutations are likely to develop triple receptor-negative andhigh-grade breast carcinomas.

questions.question: Which of the following does not increase the risk of breast carcinoma in women?
questions.explanation: Early age of first pregnancy, breastfeeding, and multiparity are protective factors for carcinoma ofthe breast. This is due to a reduction in the overall number of ovulatory cycles thereby reducingthe duration of estrogen's action on the breast tissues.

questions.question: A woman presented to the clinic with redness and itching over the left breast as shown in theimage below. Histopathology showed large pale vacuolated cells with round nuclei in theepithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture and histology are suggestive of Paget's disease of the breast.Paget's disease is a rare type of cancer involving the nipple-areolar complex, often with anunderlying in-situ or invasive ductal carcinoma. It presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption ofthe nipple which may progress to ulceration. Paget disease of the breast is often mistaken foreczema.A nipple biopsy specimen of Paget's disease will show a population of cells that are identical to theunderlying malignant cells. The presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) with roundor oval nuclei are pathognomonic for this condition.210Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy ormastectomy.Paget's diseaseEczemaLateralitUnilateralBilateralyAge groMenopausal woLactating womenupmenEdgesDistinctIndistinctVesiclesAbsentPresentNippleUsually destroyUsually intactedLumpUsually presentNo underlying lumpPaget's CellsNote: Histologically, Paget's disease can be confused with superficial spreading melanoma,particularly if they have incorporated melanin from adjacent epidermis. Paget's disease showspositive immunostaining with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), while superficial spreadingmelanoma is positive for S-100 antigen.

questions.question: Which is the most common variant of breast carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Invasive ductal carcinoma (not otherwise specified) is the most common variant of breastcarcinoma. It is also known as infiltrating ductal carcinoma.

questions.question: 205Which of the following is not true regarding breast carcinoma?

options.A: Cutaneous oedema in inflammatory carcinoma is the result of blockage of the sub-dermallymphatics with carcinoma cells
options.B: Mucinous carcinomas are usually hormone negative
options.C: Calcifications are frequently associated with ductal carcinoma in situ
options.D: Lobular carcinoma in situ is multi centric and bilateral

questions.explanation: 211Mucinous carcinoma is usually hormone-positive (90%). It is also called colloid carcinoma. It is alow-grade tumor with a good prognosis. It typically presents as a bulky mass in the elderly.Option A: Pathologic hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma is a painful, swollen breast, which iswarm with cutaneous edema due to blockage of subdermal lymphatics with carcinoma cells.Option C: Calcification is usually associated with ductal carcinoma in-situ (DCIS). It is the mostcommon malignancy detected in screening mammograms.Option D: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is mainly multicentric (sometimes multifocal) andbilateral.

questions.question: Arrange the following subtypes of breast carcinomas according to the best to worstprognosis?
questions.explanation: Tubular carcinoma has the best prognosis. questions.question: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of the right breast over the past 15days. On examination, there was local rise of temperature, and the swelling was mobile overthe chest wall. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, the rapid onset of the disease and the examination findings are suggestiveof inflammatory carcinoma of the breast.Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. It mimics acutemastitis. The hallmark of inflammatory breast carcinoma is the diffuse tumor involvement of thedermal lymphatics within the breast and the overlying skin, often without a discrete underlyingtumor mass (peau d' orange appearance). The patient presents with rapidly progressive swelling ofthe breast, warmth, erythema and edema. A breast lump may or may not be present.A diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma should be suspected when a patient with rapidlyprogressive swelling with inflammatory skin changes does not respond to antibiotics. The imagingfeatures with ultrasound and a mammograph is non-specific due to the underlying erythema andedema. A biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis.Treatment includes combined-modality treatment:212• Neoadjuvant chemotherapy•Mastectomy•••• Radiation therapyHormonal therapy- for ER-positive tumorsTrastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumorsOption B: Giant fibroadenomas occasionally occur during puberty. These are benign solidencapsulated slow-growing tumors over 5 cm in diameter. It presents as a painless lump in thebreast. They are managed by excision via a submammary incision.Option C: Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear inyounger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcomaphyllodes. It presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. They are usuallymobile over the chest wall despite their large size. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin. Nippleretraction is not seen in this condition. Benign lesions can be treated with enucleation or widelocal excision. Massive tumours, recurrent tumours and malignant lesions are treated with amastectomy.Option D: Galactocele are the most common benign breast lesions in lactating women. It is acystic enlargement of the mammary gland containing milk. They are mostly detected duringlactation or in the third trimester of pregnancy but rarely, may also present after stoppingbreastfeeding. Clinically, the mass is usually firm and non-tender and presents as a solidtumour-like lesion on physical examination. The patient usually notes thelesion during lactation or some period after lactation. Needle aspiration, followedby excision should it recur, is the standard method of treating galactocele.

questions.question: A middle-aged woman presented with a painless lump in the breast. Mammography doneshowed suspicious microcalcifications. USG-guided core biopsy revealed large cells withcytoplasmic mucoid globules and neighborhood calcifications. There is no invasion into thebasement membrane and fibrovascular stroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The presence of large cells with cytoplasmic mucoid globules with an intact basement membrane,and neighborhood calcifications are characteristic of lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS).213Lobular carcinoma in-situ is usually detected as an incidental finding on evaluation of either amass lesion or abnormalities on mammography.The slide below shows cytoplasmic mucoid globules seen in lobular carcinoma in situ.Option A: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) can have various histological appearances like solid,comedo, papillary cribriform, etcHistological appearance ofDuctal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)Papillary patternThe increased proliferation of the epitheliumthat lines the minor ducts results in thepapillary growths within the duct luminaCribriform patternThe papillary growths eventually coalesceand fill the duct lumina so that only scattered,rounded spaces remain between the clumpsof atypical cancer cellsSolid patternPleomorphic cancer cells eventuallyobliterate the lumina and distend the ductsComedo patternWith the rapid proliferation of cells, somecells do not get adequate blood supply andbecome necrotic. The ducts are filled with thenecrotic materialOption B: Histology of Paget's disease of the breast shows the presence of large pale vacuolatedcells (Paget cells) in the rete pegs of the epithelium.214Paget's CellsOption D: Histology of phyllodes tumor consists of nodules of proliferating stromal cells, that arecovered by epithelium. This resembles a leaf and is hence termed as phyllodes.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely in a woman with bilateral and multicentric breastlumps?
questions.explanation: Bilaterality and multicentricity are most commonly associated with lobular carcinoma in situ(LCIS).LCIS occurs bilaterally in 50 - 70% of cases. Multicentricity is seen in 60 - 90% of patients withLCIS.Multicentricity refers to the occurrence of second breast cancer outside the breast quadrant of theprimary cancer (or at least 4 cm away). Multifocality refers to the occurrence of a second cancerwithin the same breast quadrant as the primary cancer (or within 4 cm of it).215Multicentricity and Multifocality>4 cmsMultifocalMulticentricOMARROW

questions.question: An annual screening mammogram done for a middle-aged woman showed clusters ofmicrocalcifications. Stereotactic trucut biopsy revealed a comedo growth pattern. What is themost likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The presence of microcalcifications on mammography and comedo pattern on histology issuggestive of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).Treatment:•• Breast conservation surgery with radiotherapy or,• Simple mastectomy- least loco-regional recurrence• No role of chemotherapy••If ER, PR +ve- hormonal therapyHistological appearance ofDuctal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)Papillary patternThe increased proliferation of the epitheliumthat lines the minor ducts results in thepapillary growths within the duct luminaCribriform patternThe papillary growths eventually coalesceand fill the duct lumina so that only scattered,rounded spaces remain between the clumpsof atypical cancer cellsSolid patternPleomorphic cancer cells eventuallyobliterate the lumina and distend the ductsComedo patternWith the rapid proliferation of cells, somecells do not get adequate blood supply andbecome necrotic. The ducts are filled with thenecrotic material216Comedo subtype refers to the presence of necrosis. It implies that the tumor cells are growingrapidly and the blood vessel is not able to supply all the malignant cells. On the contrary,non-comedo subtype implies that the tumor is growing slowly and the blood vessel is able tosupply all the cells. Therefore, the comedo subtypes are of high-grade DCIS.

questions.question: A woman with BRCA1 gene mutation presented with lumps in both breasts and enlargedaxillary lymphadenopathy. She gives a history of breast cancer in her sister. MRI and trucutbiopsy done confirmed the diagnosis of medullary carcinoma of the breast. Which of thefollowing statements is true regarding the given condition?

options.A: Lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia
options.B: It is a slow growing tumor
options.C: Tamoxifen can be used in the treatment
options.D: Has poorer prognosis than invasive lobular carcinoma

questions.explanation: Medullary carcinoma of the breast is associated with intense lymphocyte proliferation. Therefore,the lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia rather than the spread of thecancer cells to the lymph nodes.Medullary carcinoma is a common type of breast cancer associated with BRCA1 gene mutation.Bilateral tumors are common when family history is present. The tumor can enlarge rapidly dueto necrosis and hemorrhage. The majority of the tumors are triple-negative (ER/PR/Her-2negative).Histopathology consists of:• A dense lymphoreticular infiltration composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells• A sheet-like growth pattern of anaplastic cells with absent ductal or lobular differentiationIt has a better prognosis than invasive ductal or invasive lobular carcinoma.Histology of medullary carcinoma breastLymphocyticinfiltrationAnaplasticcells

questions.question: 208A male patient who presented with a lump in his right breast is diagnosed to have breastcarcinoma. Which of the following is true regarding the given condition?

options.A: The prognosis is worse than in females
options.B: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type
options.D: Tamoxifen is not effective in treatment

questions.explanation: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer seen in men.Breast cancer in men accounts for less than 1% of all breast cancers. The peak incidence isbetween 60-70 years of age. Majority of the patients present with a hard mass in thebreast. Important risk factors are:217• BRCA2 mutation• Radiation exposure.Estrogen therapy⚫ Testicular feminizing syndrome⚫ Klinefelter syndrome•Diagnosis of male breast carcinoma is similar to females which involves a clinical examination,imaging, and tissue biopsy. Grading, treatment, and prognosis are the same as female breastcancer. The majority of male breast cancers are hormone receptor-positive and hence tamoxifen isused in the treatment.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman is worried about developing breast cancer. Her mother and sister haddeveloped breast cancer at the age of 30 years and 32 years respectively. She has 2 daughters.After evaluation, she is found to have a BRCA-1 gene mutation. Which of the followingmethods will you suggest for the maximum risk reduction of developing carcinoma breast inthis patient?

options.A: Close surveillance with MRI every 6 months

questions.explanation: Prophylactic mastectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy will provide maximum riskreduction in this patient with a complete family, a positive gene mutation, and positive familyhistory.•Breast cancer risk reduction techniques:Lifestyle modification: Low-calorie diet, daily exercise, no smoking, no drinking, etc.• More frequent screening every 6-12 months with mammogram +- MRI•Chemoprevention: Preferred in women >35 years of age in patients who are ER/PR positive.Given for 5-10 years.• SERMS (selective estrogen receptor modulators) - Tamoxifen and raloxifene - have adverseeffects. If a patient on tamoxifen develops abnormal uterine bleeding, the drug needs to bestopped.• Aromatase Inhibitors (AIs): Better tolerated than SERMS have a low risk of cardiovascular andendometrial complications. They are used only in post-menopausal women.• Risk-reduction surgeries: done in patients with gene mutations or patients with first-degreerelatives with breast cancers. Provides >90% risk-reduction. Preferred in patients who havecompleted their family. Best results when done < 40 years of age.• Bilateral mastectomySalpingo-oophorectomy: preferred in patients with BRCA1/2 mutations to prevent the risk ofovarian cancer too.218
